meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hat</radical> comes to a <radical>stop</radical>, thinking of a <kanji>plan</kanji>. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop.
meaning_hint: Imagine a hat walking about on your head, pacing back and forth deep in thought. See the hat stroke its chin in contemplation as it tries to think up a plan to get off your noggin and back inside.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>plan</kanji> that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the <reading>key</reading> (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple!
reading_hint: Watch as the hat begins to grin. This plan is so simple it’s sure to work. Now watch as the hat obtains the key and enters the locked door. What sort of mischief will the hat get into once inside?

meaning_mnemonic: A psychic <radical>leader</radical> can pick a <radical>thread</radical> up off the <radical>ground</radical> and make a <kanji>connection</kanji> with the person that it came from. This leader is very powerful, so even a thread is enough for them to make a psychic connection with the person who was wearing the thread.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are this leader and you just picked up this piece of thread from the ground. You get a jarring psychic connection with the owner of the thread. Your head spins, your heart races, and your hands tremble. Picture this happening to you as you pick up the thread from the ground.
reading_mnemonic: As you develop this psychic <kanji>connection</kanji> with the owner of the thread, you can tell that he is currently eating a <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい).
reading_hint: The connection is so strong that you feel like you're eating the cake as well. It’s vanilla strawberry. You taste the fluffy and creamy vanilla strawberry flavors washing over your tongue. Imagine yourself eating this delectable cake. It’s fantastically delicious.

meaning_mnemonic: If you play <radical>music</radical> with your <radical>fins</radical>, one <kanji>rule</kanji> is that you must be a fish. You can’t play music using fish fins that don’t belong to you. That’s the rule. And it’s also rude.
meaning_hint: Imagine a fish playing music using his fins. What kind of a song is it? Imagine it in your head as you see a sign with the fish fin rule on it.
reading_mnemonic: There’s also a <kanji>rule</kanji> in place to limit the amount of fish fin musicians. No more than <reading>ten</reading> (てん) are allowed to gather and play their music together. That’s the rule. No more than ten.
reading_hint: Picture a group of ten (as per the rule) fish playing music with their fins. Now the song can be louder and more intricate. Imagine it playing in your head.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets in your <radical>eye</radical>, I <kanji>dare</kanji> you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you.
meaning_hint: Looking at the sun straight on hurts. It’s bad for your eyes and burns your brain. Imagine how painful it is to stare at the sun.
reading_mnemonic: After you’ve blinded yourself from the <kanji>dare</kanji> of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge.
reading_hint: Picture yourself bowling without the power of sight. It would be awfully difficult to do well. You’d just have to concentrate really hard on the sound of the pins and determine where you need to throw the ball.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>forehead</radical> <radical>table</radical> is completely <kanji>superfluous</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Seriously, you don't need a forehead table. It's totally unnecessary to have a table made of foreheads and is a superfluous purchase. First of all, getting all those foreheads is a waste of people. Second, forehead tables aren't very strong. Superfluous, superfluous, superfluous.
reading_mnemonic: The only person you know with a <kanji>superfluous</kanji> forehead table is <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the ten foot tall, simple farmhand.
reading_hint: Now every time you visit Joe, you’ll have to look at his giant, superfluous forehead table. Imagine how gross it looks, with dozens of foreheads protruding from its surface. Only Joe would buy such a thing.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>prison</radical> on a <radical>cliff</radical> surrounded by <radical>snake</radical>s. Now that's a <kanji>dangerous</kanji> place. If you try to escape the prison you either fall to your death off the cliff or get bitten/squeezed to death by the snakes. Can you think of anything more dangerous than this? I can't.
meaning_hint: Imagine a dangerous prison surrounded by cliffs and snakes. You wouldn't want to be here either, would you?
reading_mnemonic: Lucky for you, even though you're stuck in this <kanji>dangerous</kanji> place, there is hope. There is a <reading>key</reading> (き). All dangerous prisons have a key. You just have to find and steal it so you can avoid the cliffs and snakes!
reading_hint: Imagine staring at the key dangling right outside of the dangerous prison you're trapped in. Would you take the chance and go for it?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>products</radical> radical and the <kanji>product</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Productive!
reading_mnemonic: As you try to sell these <kanji>product</kanji>s, you finally get a buyer. It's a <reading>Hin</reading>du (ひん) person. She walks in and buys your products on the spot!
reading_hint: Then another Hindu person walks in your store and buys some. Then another... What are all these Hindu people doing buying your products, you wonder? When you ask them, they tell you "it's a cultural thing."

meaning_mnemonic: You examine the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>zombie</radical> and find a small <kanji>garden</kanji> in there. There are even benches... it looks like a <kanji>park</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Zombies are dead, so I guess their mouths have all the things garden plants crave. Their mouths are like compost piles, if you think about it.
reading_mnemonic: You look closer at the <kanji>garden</kanji> and suddenly everything <reading>en</reading>ds (えん).
reading_hint: Oh. The zombie probably bit down on your head and now it's the end for you. At least you were looking at a nice garden at the end of it all...

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>narwhal</radical> <radical>stick</radical>s a <radical>child</radical> with its horn then you have to admit that it <kanji>exist</kanji>s. We know some of you have been doubting narwhals and whether they're real. Well now your kid is a kabob, so do you believe they exist now? I <kanji>suppose</kanji> you do.
meaning_hint: Imagine needing this kind of horrible proof to believe something exists. Maybe you should have more faith in what we teach.
reading_mnemonic: Oh, and the child we had to narwhal stab to prove they <kanji>exist</kanji> - that's your <reading>son</reading> (そん). Maybe you should have listened and kept your son out of the Narwhal Danger <reading>Zone</reading> (ぞん) after we warned you about it.
reading_hint: I suppose you'll never forget that narwhals exist now that your son has one permanently stuck in him.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>roof</radical> needs <radical>measurement</radical>s done every year to make sure it will <kanji>protect</kanji> you properly.
meaning_hint: If you think about it, your roof protects you from a lot of things! Rain, snow, bird poop. But if your roof's measurements are off it won't be able to protect you properly.
reading_mnemonic: If the measurements are off, and your roof doesn't <kanji>protect</kanji> you, then you get to <reading>sue</reading> (す)! If you're still alive, that is.
reading_hint: Odds are, the roof collapsed or a tree fell on you and you died from lack of protection. So now your family and friends are going to sue on your behalf.

meaning_mnemonic: Sticking a <radical>cross</radical> into a <radical>rice paddy</radical> to get its <radical>measurement</radical>s is your <kanji>specialty</kanji>. Most people get really confused when they have to measure their rice paddies, but that's where you come in. You plant a cross right in the middle, look down it from one end to the other, and voila! You know the measurements immediately. That's why it's your specialty!
meaning_hint: Visualize yourself doing this. The numbers just come to you. It's just what you're good at. Your specialty is something no one else in the world is as good at as you!
reading_mnemonic: Hearing of your amazing <kanji>specialty</kanji> and cross measurement abilities, a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) from a far off land recruits you for a job. The centaur’s father has just passed away and the centaur wants you to measure the rice paddies that have been left to him.
reading_hint: Picture yourself at a centaur funeral. Tons of centaurs standing around and stamping their hooves as you make your measurement and stick a cross into the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>lid</radical> on something <radical>spicy</radical> and you'll cook up pure <kanji>happiness</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Spicy foods literally do trigger happy chemicals in your brain. It wouldn't be too far off to say that putting a lid on a pot filled with something spicy could produce happiness.
reading_mnemonic: Out of spicy foods you made pure <kanji>happiness</kanji>. You give it to your sad friend <reading>こう</reading>いち, who waits at the table.
reading_hint: こういち looks sad. But when you serve him happiness, he starts to perk up a bit. A couple more bites of happiness, and there's a smile on his face. Although when you found こういち he was depressed, down on his luck, and hiding from the government, cooking him some spicy foods seems to have brought him some happiness.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> <radical>attach</radical>ing your entire country is the <kanji>government</kanji>. They loom over you all and try to keep you all organized and together under their control.
meaning_hint: Picture a map of the world with actual canopies attached to each government, representing the ruling governments of each place.
reading_mnemonic: Try to get out from under this <kanji>government</kanji> canopy and you'll be labeled a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). Unless... you can fool them!
reading_hint: Think of all the people who've been labeled as fools by the government because they try to detach themselves from under their reach. It's a pretty long list...

meaning_mnemonic: If you listened in to the <radical>private</radical> lives of <radical>twenty</radical> people, all of them would have different <kanji>dialect</kanji>s and ways of <kanji>speech</kanji>. Whether they actually use these dialects with you is another story. But when they're alone, or with other people who are from the same place, their speech will be different.
meaning_hint: Can you even imagine twenty different dialects in your head? Well I can tell you that there are definitely at least twenty of them in Japan alone.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to learn someone's <kanji>dialect</kanji> is to buy them a <reading>ben</reading>to (べん) from where they're from. Not only do these bento have writing in their dialect on them, but their speech will immediately shift to match. Then you'll be able to hear how they sound in their head and in private!
reading_hint: It also helps that bento are delicious, and anyone with any dialect will love them.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>wolverine</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> is in <radical>prison</radical>, so you need to <kanji>hurry</kanji> to set it free. But don't be too <kanji>sudden</kanji>, or its heart won't survive. And the wolverine's death will be on you.
meaning_hint: Imagine a dying wolverine, its heart trapped in a prison. Hurry, save it! You aren't going fast enough! Hurry, hurry!
reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>hurry</kanji> as fast as you can to save the wolverine. But you're losing strength, so you grab a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう) from your bag and munch on it to get some of your hurrying power back.
reading_hint: Cucumbers help you hurry to where you need to go. Something about the smell, crunch, and taste helps you hurry it up.

meaning_mnemonic: It's <radical>correct</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> to focus on <kanji>politics</kanji> and the <kanji>government</kanji>. Elections are happening, in the new year politicians are being sworn in. Winter is government time!
meaning_hint: Imagine all this politics and government talk as you shiver outside in the winter cold. You’re freezing and you’re bored, but you know this is the right (correct) thing to do.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone involved in <kanji>politics</kanji> and <kanji>government</kanji> wields a special <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). If two political parties are arguing, they'll whip out their sabers and start slashing away!
reading_hint: Picture two different politicians, both wielding sabers, fighting to make the government the way they want it to be! Who are you rooting for?

meaning_mnemonic: As the <radical>sun</radical> rises over the hills, the ferocious <radical>wolverine</radical> stalks a <radical>turkey</radical> on a <kanji>weekday</kanji> morning. The wolverine hunts turkeys for a living, but on the weekends, he likes to play racquetball at the local gym. That’s why the turkey is getting hunted on a weekday.
meaning_hint: You’ve probably seen those nature shows like on National Geographic. Think back to one of those shows where the hunter stalks its prey and leaps out in slow motion to do the murder. Now imagine this scene with the wolverine leaping out at the turkey. The wolverine howls a bloodcurdling shriek as the turkey lurches in agony, feathers flying everywhere as the wolverine sinks its teeth into flesh.
reading_mnemonic: This wolverine has a strange palate, however. It likes to turn its turkey into turkey <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). After the hunt every <kanji>weekday</kanji>, the wolverine spends the evening turning the turkey meat into a strange, thick and chunky, turkey yogurt.
reading_hint: Imagine eating this turkey yogurt. It tastes pretty much exactly how you would expect. Chunks of turkey meat mixed with thick and creamy yogurt. It tastes like mushy Thanksgiving. Imagine eating this every day of the week.

meaning_mnemonic: Why would you try to take a <radical>brush</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical>? It's almost too obvious, because you want to <kanji>write</kanji> something down.
meaning_hint: Just imagine yourself sitting on the sun, writing back to your friends and family with a brush. For someone who can visit the sun, it's really weird that you are writing with a brush like this, but you're doing it just the same.
reading_mnemonic: What did you <kanji>write</kanji> about? You were writing about this amazing circus <reading>show</reading> (しょ) you just watched on the sun. You didn't expect there to be any shows here, but turns out you were wrong!
reading_hint: Think of your favorite live shows and imagine them on the sun. Also imagine yourself writing back to your friends and family about said shows.

meaning_mnemonic:
After a <radical>tsunami</radical>, use this <radical>machine</radical> to <kanji>cure</kanji> the people and the country from the damage. <kanji>Heal</kanji>ing machines are all over Japan just in case a tsunami does way more damage than they can handle. 

Oh, and whoever cures and heals the most people will be able to <kanji>rule</kanji> over them once everything starts going back to normal. So keep that in mind, kay?
meaning_hint: Imagine if you had your own machine to cure yourself if a tsunami came to where you live. It would be pretty convenient!
reading_mnemonic:
Alternative ways to <kanji>cure</kanji> yourself after a tsunami are either praying to <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) or eating your weight in <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). I'm not sure if I have enough cheese for all the people that got hit though... Hmm, do you have cheese?

Before you make your decision, remember that whoever cures you will be able to <kanji>reign</kanji> over you and your people. So do you want to be led by Jesus or by some cheese? The choice is yours.
reading_hint: Imagine getting Jesus to cure half the people and feeding the other half lots of cheese and their wounds miraculously healing on their own! You're a hero!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>valley</radical>, filling it up with water. Lucky for you, you're a giant, so you just lay down in the valley and use it to <kanji>bathe</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Sure, there's a lot of water in the valley, but you're big too. It's the perfect place for you to bathe... and good thing too, you're getting smelly.
reading_mnemonic: You know what would make the <kanji>bath</kanji>ing experience even better? If you had some egg <reading>yolk</reading>s (よく) to eat. Just crack those yolks into the water you bathe in, and it'll cook to perfection. Yum!
reading_hint: Imagine cooking egg yolks in the same water you bathe in.

meaning_mnemonic: A group of <radical>private</radical> <radical>sword</radical> guys are in your <radical>rice paddy</radical>. You must <kanji>detain</kanji> them at once! Private sword guys are people who work for private companies and use their swords on people. They're basically paid assassins. And you're going to detain them!
meaning_hint: Imagine running into the rice paddy and detaining the private sword holders one by one. They won't get away this time!
reading_mnemonic:
You're running out of steam and you're afraid you might not be able to <kanji>detain</kanji> all of these guys when <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter appears. He hates swords, and will only use fists because it's the honorable way to fight, so he starts helping you detain them!

He's also found a <reading>loo</reading>phole (る) in the system and you don't have to be super gentle with these guys either. So detain them as forcefully as you want. It is your rice paddy they're in, after all.
reading_hint: If Ryu hadn't shown up with this loophole you never would have detained all these private sword guys by yourself!

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>pope</radical> spends all day staring at <radical>fins</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>, he’s going to lose touch with <kanji>reality</kanji>. He should be focusing on his popish duties, but instead he’s looking at the fish fins he dropped, and now can’t eat because they’re dirty. Silly pope. You can’t let this one thing get you down. You have other things to do.
meaning_hint: Picture trying to get the pope to stop staring at the fins lying on the dirty ground. His eyes are all big. Yup, he’s completely lost touch with reality, you think.
reading_mnemonic: You’re doing your best to bring the pope back to <kanji>reality</kanji> when he snaps and kicks you in the <reading>shin</reading> (しん). Oww! What the heck, pope! But he’s already back staring at the fins and your shin is throbbing where he kicked.
reading_hint: Imagine the pope angrily kicking your shin super hard. You fall over and pull it close. Feel how badly it aches. Who knew you’d need shin guards to deal with a pope that’s lost touch with reality just from dropping his dinner.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Bamboo</radical> <radical>heaven</radical> is a place for <kanji>laugh</kanji>ing. Bamboo is a very jolly plant, and they love to laugh. Even after death in bamboo heaven, the bamboo continue to laugh joyfully. Bamboo heaven is truly a place of laughter.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as a bamboo plant that laughs in heaven. What are you laughing about? Chuckle to yourself as you remember this kanji.
reading_mnemonic: There’s actually a war a goin’ on up in that there bamboo heaven, y’know? Ye might not have heard of it with all that there <kanji>laugh</kanji>in’ a goin’ on, but there definitely be a <reading>war a</reading> (わら) goin’ on up in bamboo heaven, y’hear? The bamboo are scared so that’s why they be laughin’ so much. They nervous.
reading_hint: Now picture these bamboo again up in bamboo heaven, and remember this strange accent to remember that the bamboo plants up in bamboo heaven are laughing with nervous laughter at this bamboo war that’s a goin’ on up there.

meaning_mnemonic: Having a keen <radical>eye</radical> for woodworking, you can tell that the <radical>bamboo</radical> from that <radical>tree</radical> over there will make an excellent <kanji>box</kanji>. Boxes made from bamboo trees are very sturdy and fashionable. You have an eye for fashion as well, you see.
meaning_hint: At some point in school, you most likely had some sort of woodshop class to take. Remember back to those times and imagine yourself crafting a bamboo box out of a bamboo tree you felled yourself. Don’t forget to wear eye protection though! Wouldn’t want anything to happen to those valuable eyes of yours.
reading_mnemonic: Now you can use that <kanji>box</kanji> to store all your <reading>har</reading>d<reading>co</reading>re (はこ) punk vinyls. You’re a real connoisseur, so you know that hardcore music should only ever be kept in bamboo boxes.
reading_hint: Picture yourself filling up your lovingly crafted bamboo box with your collection of hardcore punk and rock records. Ah, they fit just perfectly thanks to that discerning eye of yours.

meaning_mnemonic: You offer <radical>flowers</radical> to your <radical>leader</radical> and compliment them on their <radical>lip ring</radical>. You think that by doing this they might carry your <kanji>luggage</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Picture this big, strong leader. They actually love flowers and feel flattered by your compliment! But being the leader, they can't help wondering why they should have to carry your luggage…
reading_mnemonic: Unconvinced by your flattery, the leader refuses to carry your <kanji>luggage</kanji>, so you get on your <reading>knee</reading>s (に) and beg them to carry it.
reading_hint: On top of being a strong leader, they also have a very kind heart, so your begging convinces them and they agree to carry your luggage.

meaning_mnemonic: What I <radical>say</radical> is <radical>correct</radical> 100%! You may use it as <kanji>evidence</kanji> in this murder case.
meaning_hint: You convince the officials questioning you that your evidence can be trusted and it's <kanji>proof</kanji> that you definitely didn't have anything to do with any law breaking or murdering.
reading_mnemonic: The officials force you to present this <kanji>evidence</kanji> in front of the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう), himself. Your knees quake, you feel like you're gonna be sick, but you try to stand up tall and tell him everything. After all, you know your <kanji>proof</kanji> is correct, so you shouldn't be so scared.
reading_hint: You better hope the Shougun believes your evidence is accurate, because he's known to kill people willy-nilly when he thinks they're lying.

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <radical>tongue</radical> becomes too <radical>spicy</radical> for you to bear, it’s time to <kanji>quit</kanji> the jalapeño eating contest. You’ve been eating them for three hours now and the spiciness from the peppers is really burning your tongue. Throw in the towel, it’s time to quit the contest.

This kanji has another meaning too:

Eating isn't the only thing that makes your <radical>tongue</radical> <radical>spicy</radical>, so do certain <kanji>word</kanji>s. Say your favorite words out loud right now. Feel them on your tongue. Words are the spicy food of language!
meaning_hint: You may have to quit eating but you never have to quit saying words. Especially if you're, well, trying to learn a whole new language full of them.
reading_mnemonic: Oh, you're probably wondering who won that spicy food contest after you <kanji>quit</kanji> and became obsessed with <kanji>word</kanji>s instead. It was <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). Who did you expect? He was great with words AND never quitting when things got spicy.
reading_hint: Picture Jesus scarfing down jalapeño peppers. He never quits. And then he says some words about how the jalapeños gave up their lives for this contest, so we better appreciate them. Thanks Jesus!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>scooter</radical> with a <radical>zombie</radical> on it, going really <kanji>far</kanji> away. Someone tied that zombie to the scooter and now it's far off in the distance, groaning and growling.
meaning_hint: Picture the zombie, going far off into the distance. It's getting smaller and harder to see.
reading_mnemonic: The zombie goes so <kanji>far</kanji>, that its life <reading>en</reading>ds (えん). Zombies need to eat to live (it's really all they need), but they go so far on their scooter trip, that they just give up and end it all.
reading_hint: I mean, to be fair, the zombie wasn't really alive to begin with. But going far enough to end it all? That's some serious distance!

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>gate</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>gates</kanji> are the same!
meaning_hint: Know your radicals or you won't be allowed to pass.
reading_mnemonic: You want to pass through this <kanji>gate</kanji> but it’s guarded by… a <reading>mon</reading>ster (もん)!
reading_hint: Picture the most terrifying monster you can imagine, standing as tall as the gate itself. How on earth are you ever going to get past that thing?!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>gate</radical> of <radical>horns</radical> will take you to <radical>heaven</radical>. These horns are <kanji>related</kanji> and <kanji>connected</kanji> to heaven in some way.
meaning_hint: Perhaps they are related to heaven because the devil has horns? Perhaps they are connected to heaven because these are the horns of heaven's enemies? The real reason they're connected will be revealed in the reading mnemonic.
reading_mnemonic: They are <kanji>related</kanji> and <kanji>connected</kanji> to heaven because these are the horns that Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) made from his enemies. God said he could come into heaven if he made a gate of horns, so that's what he did.
reading_hint: Imagine Genghis Khan taking horns off his enemies, and making a gate to heaven. The horn gate is connected to both heaven and Genghis Khan in that way.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <radical>anti</radical>-<radical>building</radical>, you're probably afraid of <kanji>heights</kanji> and <kanji>slopes</kanji>. The only downside to a building is that they're high and if you fall off of them you could die. So if someone says they're anti-building, they're really just anti-heights.
meaning_hint: Imagine standing on the edge of a very high building. If you feel sick or upset, you may be one of these anti-height people!
reading_mnemonic: Another person you know who's afraid of <kanji>heights</kanji> is <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. Now wait, you may be thinking, he flies a space ship! You're right, because he doesn't like to walk all the way up high buildings, it freaks him out. He flies up instead so he doesn't have to think about falling.
reading_hint: Imagine standing at the top of a tall building with Han Solo. He's very afraid of heights. They make him nervous. Like something bad will happen if he were to ever stand above a big pit, high up.

meaning_mnemonic: Going into a <radical>building</radical> made by a <radical>squid</radical> is <kanji>risky</kanji>. First of all, squids only have tentacles, no bones, and they make all of their buildings out of risky materials like kelp and sharp coral.
meaning_hint: One squid got stuck in his own building, but no one could save him because going in would be too risky. Poor little squid.
reading_mnemonic: "It's too <kanji>risky</kanji>, leave me!" the squid cries. "I'll save you, underwater citizen! Nothing is too risky for <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai!" The building is collapsing on the squid, the risk is so great, but Ken the samurai dives in and saves him!
reading_hint:
The squid cries, "I can build one that isn't so risky next time!" Ken shakes his head, "I'm not letting you do anymore risky things, you're coming with me from now on." Ken scoops up the squid into a bucket, hoists him over his shoulder, and walks off into the sunset.

Who knows what adventures await our new duo. All we know is that they'll definitely be getting into some risky business.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>face</radical> radical and the <kanji>face</kanji> kanji are the same! But this isn't just a face like the one you're looking at your computer/phone with. It's the <kanji>surface</kanji> kind of face too!
meaning_hint: The next time you look at your face, also notice how much surface area it has.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>face</kanji> you're looking at, that has a lot of <kanji>surface</kanji> area, belongs to <reading>men</reading> (めん). Not a single man, but all men put together. It's hundreds of thousands of men's faces in a row.
reading_hint: Look at the face of all men put together. Measure how much surface area they all take up.
